Award.AwardTitle: On the Occurrence of Resonance in Elastic-Dissipative Coupled Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Galdi
DMS-1614011

Over the past two decades, the study of the motion of a viscous liquid in the presence of rigid or deformable bodies has become one of the main focuses of applied research. The aim of this project is to address significant aspects of the above type of phenomenon and is directed toward the accomplishment of the following objectives. The first one regards occurrence of resonance phenomena in the interaction of a viscous liquid with an elastic structure. For example, in the context of modeling of arterial blood flow it is of the utmost importance to find out whether, for a given model, the pulsatile action of the heart pumping blood would produce an unrealistic high-amplitude oscillation of the arterial wall. The second one deals with the so-called vortex-induced oscillations of a structure in the uniform stream of a viscous liquid. This phenomenon is considered to play a major role in the collapse of chimneys and bridges under wind load. The most famous event in this sense is probably the failure of the Tacoma Narrows bridge.

From a technical viewpoint, the above questions are addressed by studying the existence of time-periodic solutions and the occurrence of Hopf bifurcation in coupled systems of nonlinear hyperbolic-parabolic equations that model fluid-structure interactions. One of the main focuses of this project is to understand whether the dissipative mechanism (the parabolic component of the system) can prevent the occurrence of resonance in the elastic structure (the hyperbolic component). Some of these problems need to be formulated in unbounded spatial domains, like infinite pipeline systems or regions exterior to a finite number of bodies. The latter may add an even further complication, in that the linearized relevant operators may possess, in such cases, a non-empty essential spectrum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past two decades, the study of the interaction of a viscous liquid with a rigid or elastic stracture has become one of the main focuses of applied mathematics. Objective of this research was to investigate some among the many intriguing and challenging problems pertaining to  this and other related areas of investigation. In particular, the PI has aimed his efforts at the study of  the interaction of time-periodic flow of a viscous liquid with a structure. The liquid flow may either be  forced, namely, generated by the action of external body forces acting on the liquid or on the structure, or else be the outcome of a spontaneous self-oscillation due to a bifurcation phenomenon from a steady-state. 

Significant cases that have been successfuly studied regard the following two categories of problems. (i) A time-periodic force is acting on an  elastic structure embedded in a viscous liquid. In absence of liquid, the frequency of the force would make  the structure to collapse whenever it coincides with a natural frequency of the structure. The question is whether the presence of the liquid will be sufficient to dissipate the oscillation of the structure and to avoid its collapse; (ii) A rigid body is vibrating in a viscous liquid. Determine under which conditions (frequency, mass, "size" of the body, etc.) the body will be able to produce a net motion (vibration-induced propulsion).  

Both categories of problems stem from as many significant research areas in applied science. For instance, pulsatile blood flow in arteries and vortex-induced oscillations of a structure in the uniform stream of a viscous liquid are examples of problems belonging to the first category. Likewise,  vibration-induced propulsion is suitable for capsule-type microrobots designed for motion in a strongly restricted space and in a vulnerable media, like inside a human body for a drug delivery.
